ur_rna.Utilities

Class CommandLineParser.FlagArg

  • java.lang.Object
    • ur_rna.Utilities.CommandLineParser.Argument
      • ur_rna.Utilities.CommandLineParser.FlagArg
  • Enclosing class:
    CommandLineParser

    public static class CommandLineParser.FlagArg
extends CommandLineParser.Argument
    Flags arguments are indicated by a preceding hyphen (-) or slash (/). Flag arguments have a flag field which indicates the flag definition that provided the rules for parsing and producing this FlagArg object. Some flags have parameters (which can be optional, required, or forbidden/not allowed). If a parameter value is encountered during parsing, it is stored in the valueText field, which is null in Flags for which no parameter value was encountered.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      CommandLineParser.FlagDef flag
      The Flag associated with this Argument, which specifies the name (and aliases) of the flag as well as the rules used to parse it.
      java.lang.String flagText
      Gets the actual flag name from the command-line, without any parameter value or separator that might have been present.
      java.lang.Object parsedValue
      Gets the value of this flag once it has been converted to the type specified in the associated Flag
      java.lang.String valueText
      Gets the value of this flag, if one was specified, or null otherwise.

    • Field Detail

      • flag

        public final CommandLineParser.FlagDef flag
        The Flag associated with this Argument, which specifies the name (and aliases) of the flag as well as the rules used to parse it.

      • flagText

        public final java.lang.String flagText
        Gets the actual flag name from the command-line, without any parameter value or separator that might have been present.

        When a FlagArg is parsed, the flag name (e.g. "-f" ) is used to associate it with a FlagDef. From that point on, the FlagArg can be retrieved using the FlagDef name (e.g. "file") or any of its aliases. Usually the actual flag name (-f vs -file) is not relevant, but the name is stored in case some implementation requires it.

      • parsedValue

        public final java.lang.Object parsedValue
        Gets the value of this flag once it has been converted to the type specified in the associated Flag

      • valueText

        public final java.lang.String valueText
        Gets the value of this flag, if one was specified, or null otherwise.
